comment.author: 9736611@N02
comment._content: Riverside was the location of the farm where Eliza Tibbets  planted the first two naval orange trees brought from Brazil. One of these trees, The "Parent Naval Orange Tree" is still growing in Riverside (with tons of horticultural help, of course!).

comment.author: 34586311@N05
comment._content: Thanks for the additional information! Of course, I wanted to know more about Eliza Tibbets and naval oranges in Riverside... For anyone else who wants to know a bit more, read the Wikipedia article on E Tibbets -- her life story won't disappoint!

comment.author: 9984183@N04
comment._content:
If I'm not mistaken, Mt. Rubidoux is pictured in the upper left corner.  The peak about midway across the slide is Box Springs. The University of California, Riverside is near Box Springs. 
Thanks for a terrific shot of what my hometown looked like at one time!

comment.author: 34586311@N05
comment._content:
What good eyes you have! I can't quite see him clearly, but I *think* I can see what you see...

These images give great perspective, don't they?

comment.author: 9984183@N04
comment._content:
I've added notes to highlight the two features.
I was trying to figure out where this was taken, and it is probably near the present day site of the Riverside National Cemetery, near what in now March ARB, formerly March Air Force Base.
Most of the citrus trees left are in private yards and some still at UCR research labs.
I've always known the citrus history of Riverside, but I've never seen it quite like this.

comment.author: 34586311@N05
comment._content:
It's my own poor reading comprehension! If I am looking for Mt. rather than Mr. it is perfectly clear!

Yes, Eliza's is quite a story -- working at a university with an agriculture focus, it make me wonder what people are caring for and cultivating in their own backyards... 

Do you think any of these orchards could be UCR research labs now?

comment.author: 9984183@N04
comment._content:
All of these orchards are gone, covered over by streets and housing.
Old time Riversiders still speak about the smell of orange blossoms hanging in the air. They also talk about the soot and smell from smudge pots which were used to protect the fruit from the occasional freeze.
The taller trees were planted to indicate the roads going through the groves.

comment.author: 113259926@N06
comment._content: What a beautiful sight this was.  Its a shame what it looks like now. I am a Riverside Native I still live here, I live 1 block from Historic Victoria Ave. Its just not the same. All there is now is homes,, Its just heartbreaking!!!  My family worked for the Citrus Belt all of their lives, (both my parents)  My father left me a Valencia Orange Tree,  a lime tree, a lemon tree, and 2 avocado trees in our backyard. Thank You Dad!!!!!!!!!!!!
